Project Description  The Project will work with both the national and the provincial 
governments.  At  the  national  level,  the  Project  will  help  the 
Government  strengthen  sector  planning  and  management  by 
developing  a  sector  strategy,  a  road  map,  and  an  investment 
program. A public–private partnership (PPP) framework will also 
be  prepared  together  with  the  sector  strategy  to  enable  the 
Government to promote private sector involvement in the sector 
more effectively. At the provincial level, the Project will provide 
safe,  reliable,  and  sustainable  water  supply  and  improved 
sanitation services in seven districts and one city in Surkhandarya 
Province.  The  services  can  be  used  as  a  model  that  can  be 
replicated and expanded in other provinces. Besides investments 
in physical infrastructure for system rehabilitation and necessary 
upgrading,  the  Project  will  address  the  critical  planning, 
management, financial, operational, and customer relations needs 
of  the  vodokanals  (water  supply  and  sanitation  agencies)  to 
improve service delivery efficiency.  
   
Rationale  The water supply and sanitation (WSS) systems in Uzbekistan, 
which were inherited from the Soviet Union, have reached the end 
of their economic life and require extensive rehabilitation. The 
provision of reliable, safe, and affordable WSS services to the 
population is a key challenge to the Government, as the sector is 
faced with a series of issues, including deteriorated infrastructure, 
outdated sector strategy and planning, inappropriate standards, 
limited financial resources, and weak institutional capacity. The 
sector performance indicators for 2006 show that, despite high 
network coverage (82% of the population—88% urban and 79% 
rural), households are supplied with water for only 6–24 hours a 
day in the urban areas and 2–12 hours a day in the rural areas. 
Surkhandarya has network coverage of 76% (87% urban and 74% 
rural). Water supply in the province is available for 6–16 hours a 
day  in  the  urban  areas  and  2–10  hours  in  the  rural  areas. 
Nonperforming  (deteriorated  and  leaking)  infrastructure,  power 
outages, and lack of revenue prevent better service. No reliable

estimate on unaccounted-for water (UFW) is available because of 
a  lack  of  meters;  the  general  estimate  is  more  than  50% 
nationwide.  Improving  the  health  and  living  conditions  of  the 
people by providing them with better access to safe and reliable 
water supply and better sanitation is therefore the Government’s 
top priority. The Project will support water supply and sanitation 
sector development in Uzbekistan by tackling four challenges: (i) 
shortfalls in policy and standards, (ii) investment needs, (iii) sector 
and business management, and (iv) operational and institutional 
gaps. 
   
Impact and Outcome  When  it  is  completed  in  2014,  the  Project  will  improve  living 
standards and public health for about 340,000 people living in 
Surkhandarya  Province.  The  outcome  will  be  safe,  reliable, 
inclusive, and sustainable water supply and sanitation services 
and improved community hygiene, in particular: (i) an increase in 
the duration of water supply services to 20 hours a day by 2014 
and 24 hours a day by 2020, (ii) a reduction in UFW to less than 
40%, (iii) full cost recovery for all project vodokanals from 2014 
onward, and (iv) prompt recording of and response to  customer 
complaints.  The  Project  will  achieve  this  impact  and  these 
outcomes by (i) strengthening sector planning, management, and 
regulation capacity, (ii) rehabilitating water supply and sanitation 
systems  and  facilities,  (iii)  addressing  social  and  gender 
impediments  to  equality  of  access  to  services;  (iv)  enhancing 
public awareness and practice of good hygiene, and (v) improving 
the management and the skills and capability of vodokanals.

Allocation and Relending  The  Government  has  requested  the  Asian  Development  Bank 
Terms  (ADB)  for  a  loan  in  special  drawing  rights,  equivalent  to 
$30 million from its Special Funds resources. The loan will have a 
term of 32 years, including a grace period of 8 years, and an 
interest charge of 1% yearly during the grace period and 1.5% 
yearly thereafter. The Government will relend the proceeds of the 
loan to the Uzbekistan Communal Services Agency (UCSA) under 
a subsidiary loan agreement. The relending will be made on ADB 
loan terms, with an additional charge of not more than 0.2% on 
the ADB interest rate (1.2% during the grace period and 1.7% 
yearly thereafter). UCSA will onlend the subsidiary loan proceeds 
to  the  Surkhandarya  provincial  government  (SPG),  which  will 
further onlend the proceeds to the subproject vodokanals, on the 
same  terms.  SPG  will  bear  the  foreign  exchange  risks.  The 
Government  has  also  requested  grant  financing  for  the 
strengthening of sector strategy and management (component 1) 
and  capacity  development  for  service  delivery  (component  4) 
under the Project. To finance these two components,  the Multi-
Donor Trust Fund under the Water Financing Partnership Facility 
will provide a grant of $1.5 million equivalent to be administered 
by ADB.

Implementation  UCSA will be the Executing Agency for the Project. UCSA has 
Arrangements/Plan  extensive experience in implementing projects funded by external 
agencies.  A  project  steering  committee  under  a  deputy  prime

responsible  for  day-to-day  subproject  implementation  in 
Surkhandarya Province will also be set up. 
 
To guide project implementation, a project implementation plan 
based  on  the  project  schedule,  implementation  arrangements, 
procurement  packages,  and  assurances  from  the  Government 
has been developed during project preparation. The plan specifies 
the key project management, implementation, and auditing and 
reporting  activities  during  project  implementation  with  clear 
starting and due dates for each activity, responsible parties, and 
links between project activities.

Consulting Services  A  total  of  568  person-months  of  consulting  services  (51 
international and 517 national) will be required to (i) develop a 
water  supply  and  wastewater  sector  strategy  and  investment 
program, (ii) prepare contract packages and tender documents, 
(iii) supervise  construction  and  evaluate  project  activities, 
(iv) guide and supervise resettlement, (v) monitor the social and 
gender and environmental impact of the Project, (vi) coordinate 
the  capacity  development  program,  (vii) implement  the  school 
sanitation  and  hygiene  program,  and  (viii)  support  the  other 
activities of the PMU and PIU. The selection and engagement of 
consulting services to be financed by ADB will be carried out in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants 
(2007, as amended from time to time) and the procurement plan. 
The selection will be based on one of the following: (i) the quality 
and cost of the services, according to the technical proposal (full 
or  simplified);  (ii) the  consultants’  qualifications,  for  small 
assignments that cost less than $200,000 per contract; or (iii) 
individual  consultant  selection  for  very  small  consultant 
assignments that cost less than $100,000.

v
Project Benefits and  The Project will benefit about 340,000 residents in the project 
Beneficiaries  areas by 2014 by providing safe, reliable, and inclusive piped 
water supply, improving sanitation, and promoting good hygiene. 
The duration of water supply services will be increased to 20 
hours a day by 2014 and 24 hours a day by 2020, unaccounted-
for water will be reduced to less than 40%, all project vodokanals 
will achieve full cost recovery from 2014 onward, and customer 
complaints  will  be  recorded  and  responded  to  promptly.  The 
Project will benefit about 20% of the population of the province, 
and nearly 90% of the urban residents and over 30% of the rural 
residents of the seven project districts and Termez City. About 
32% of the project beneficiaries are poor. While both men and 
women will benefit from the Project, women will benefit more from 
time savings, less drudgery, and better family health. In addition, 
the Project will help the Government draw up a coherent vision 
and strategy for WSS sector development. The PPP framework 
will enable the Government to engage private participation more 
efficiently in the sector. The institutional reforms that will transform 
vodokanals  into  business-oriented  service  providers—financial 
and  tariff  reforms,  customer  registration,  complaint  response 
mechanism,  and  performance  benchmarking—together  with 
management  tools  and  capacity  development  programs,  will 
provide vodokanals with more internal incentives and capability to 
deliver better WSS services. 
   
Risks and Assumptions  Five possible risks have been identified and addressed in the 
project  design.  First,  the  risk  of  lack  of  commitment  to  a 
comprehensive  sector  strategy  and  investment  program  is 
addressed by the broadly consultative and participatory approach 
to  the  strategy  study,  to  ensure  government  ownership  of  the 
strategy, road map, and investment program. Second, to avert 
delays in project start-up caused by the delayed preparation and 
approval of a nationwide feasibility study, feasibility studies for all 
subprojects have been conducted and completed in parallel with 
the project preparation and the Government has endorsed these 
studies before loan negotiations. Third, to forestall delays in the 
provision  of  local  counterpart  funds,  assurances  have  been 
obtained from the Government that it will allocate and provide the 
funds on time. Fourth, given the limited capability of vodokanals to 
meet  the  incremental  operation  and  maintenance  costs  of  the 
expanded  water  supply  systems,  the  capacity  development 
component  of  the  Project  includes  management  improvement 
activities, tariff and financial reforms, and targeted training. Lastly, 
to  guard  against  the  adverse  effects  of  resettlement  and 
affordability  issues  on  poor  and  vulnerable  households,  the 
resettlement plans and other due-diligence arrangements ensure 
that all affected people will improve or at least maintain their living 
standards  after  the  Project,  and  that  connection  charges  are 
removed and payment for meters is spread over 3 years.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Republic of Uzbekistan for the Surkhandarya Water Supply and Sanitation Project (the 
Project). 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
2.  Uzbekistan has a population of 26.6 million (2006), about 9.6 million of these, or 37%, 
living in urban centers and 17 million, or 63%, in rural areas. Because of the wide range of 
environments in the country, population density varies significantly, from 59 persons per square 
kilometer  (km2)  in  the  fertile  Fergana  Valley  to  6.6  persons  per  km2  in  the  central  Navoi 
Province. Traditionally populations were grouped around natural water sources including the 
Fergana Valley and old cities like Bukhara, Samarkhand, and Kiva.  
 
3.  Among the regions in the country, Surkhandarya, with a population of about 1.92 million, 
is the eighth most populous. Termez City (population 127,000) and Denau City (population 
68,000) are the main urban centers. A World Bank poverty study (2000) estimated that 28.4% of 
the population of Surkhandarya Province had incomes below the poverty line.1 The province, 
located near the border with Afghanistan, has been a closed province for many years, but 
recent developments promoting Silk Road tourism and the construction of a new rail link has led 
to  opportunities  for  growth.  Surkhandarya  is  one  of  the  main  cotton-growing  provinces  in 
Uzbekistan, with about 200,000 hectares under irrigated cotton. Most of the rural population is 
involved in growing, harvesting, and ginning cotton. 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
4.  A massive irrigated agriculture expansion program was undertaken by the Soviet Union 
in Uzbekistan in the 1960s and 1970s. Irrigation was based around 1,500- to 5,000-hectare 
collective  farms.  Communities  were  established  on  each  collective  farm  and  supplied  with 
potable water from a system sourced and developed separately from the irrigation system. 
Provincial and district centers served these communes as urban administrative and commercial 
centers—a post-independence function they still have. 
 
5.  Water is largely supplied from groundwater sources several tens of kilometers from the 
service area, pumped to distribution centers, and distributed to towns and villages. As local 
reserves of groundwater are often saline or inadequate, they are supplemented with water 
supplied through a series of regional and interregional trunk mains. Under the Soviet Union, the 
systems  were  overdesigned,  based  on  limited  evaluation  of  technical  options,  used  high 
consumption  rates  (three times  the  current  average  in  the  Organisation  for  Economic 
Co-operation and Development countries), and cost a great deal to maintain and operate. Water 
production facilities and customer connections were not metered, so consumption and tariffs 
were based on normative values. Furthermore, all facilities were owned and operated by public 
enterprises supervised by government ministries and were routinely subsidized from the state 
budget. A 20% decline in gross domestic product after independence affected the availability of 
funding to the water supply and sanitation (WSS) sector, which thus became unable to operate 
and maintain the systems.

6.  Water Supply. At independence in 1991, it was claimed that 89% of the population had 
access  to  potable  water.  Reports  for  2006  from  vodokanals 2 (WSS  agencies)  and  the 
Uzbekistan Communal Services Agency (UCSA) estimated network coverage at 82% of the 
total population (88% of the urban population and 79% of the rural population). Households, 
however, are supplied with water 6–24 hours a day in the urban areas and 2–12 hours3 a day in 
the countryside. Surkhandarya Province has a network coverage of 76% (87% urban and 74% 
rural). Water is available 6–16 hours a day in the urban areas and 2–10 hours in the rural areas. 
Nonperforming (deteriorated and leaking) infrastructure, power outages, and lack of revenue 
prevent better service. With water supply services so inadequate and unreliable, the people 
resort to collecting water from untreated open sources like canals and streams or paying for 
water from vendors or tankers. Only 10% of houses are metered, making it difficult to assess 
actual  performance  and  consumption.  Consumption  is  therefore  assessed  on  the  basis  of 
normative demand values.  
 
7.  Nationwide, unaccounted-for water (UFW) from physical losses is officially estimated at 
41%, but, given the deteriorated state of the infrastructure, this figure is considered low. In 
Surkhandarya Province, combined with nonpayment of bills, UFW is possibly greater than 60%. 
The  major  causes  of  UFW  are  system  losses  due  to  (i)  leakage  from  deteriorated  WSS 
infrastructure  at  source,  along  the  distribution  networks,  and  at  consumer  points; 
(ii) overestimation of the amount of water produced, based on the normal capacity of the source 
rather  than  actual  production;  (iii)  illegal  connections;  and  (iv)  water  wastage  due  to  the 
irregularity of water supply and the lack of meters. 
 
8.  Sanitation.  Uzbekistan  has  265  cities  and  urban  settlements.  Of  these,  69  have 
wastewater treatment systems. The Government estimates sewerage system coverage at 51% 
of the population. However, most of the systems are not functioning properly. Rural and urban 
populations not served by a centralized system use pit latrines near their homes. Termez, the 
capital city of Surkhandarya Province, has a municipal wastewater treatment plant, which is now 
being rehabilitated and upgraded.4  
 
9.  Government Policy. Uzbekistan’s WSS policy and regulatory framework derives legal 
force from (i) the national 10-year water supply development plan approved by the cabinet of 
ministers in 1999 (Resolution of the Cabinet of Ministers (RCM) No. 278),5 (ii) a resolution of the 
cabinet of ministers approved in 2003 (RCM No. 405),6 and (iii) the water supply investment 
program for 2009–2012.7 The key objectives of the WSS policy are to (i) improve water sector 
services through a national water supply development plan; (ii) attain financial sustainability 
through  an  effective  tariff  system  and  cost  recovery;  (iii)  plan  adequate  investments  with 
domestic  and  external  funding;  (iv)  achieve  further  decentralization  of  WSS  services;  (v) 
encourage  private  sector  participation  and  public-private  partnerships  in  the  sector;  (vi) 
implement  hygiene  and  sanitation  education  programs  in  schools;  (vii)  achieve  improved

10.  Sector  Institutions.  Three  main  government  agencies  have  been  entrusted  with 
regulatory  responsibilities  related  to  water  resource  management  and  conservation.  The 
Ministry of Agriculture and Water Resources has overall responsibility for all large-scale surface 
water development for irrigation. The State Committee on Geology and Mineral Resources is 
responsible for groundwater investigation, management, monitoring, and protection. The State 
Inspectorate for Regulating the Use of Water in Industry and Mining regulates the exploration, 
development, and conservation of thermal and mineral water.  
 
11.  UCSA has overall responsibility for improving WSS services in the country. It (i) drafts 
policies, strategies, and standards for the sector; (ii) provides regulatory advice to support 
reforms in the sector; (iii) monitors the compliance of local authorities and commercial entities 
with sector policies; and (iv) attracts foreign investment to the sector. The Ministry of Economy, 
in collaboration with UCSA, has a significant role in sector planning, while the Ministry of 
Finance reviews tariffs and controls and approves external financing for the sector. The State 
Committee for De-monopolization and Supporting Competition and Entrepreneurship monitors 
applications for tariffs for all communal services, including WSS. The Department of Finance in 
each province is authorized to approve tariffs, which are prepared by the urban and district 
vodokanals in their respective provinces. 
 
12.  The State Committee for Nature Protection is entrusted with the task of protecting and 
managing  the  environment.  The  state  committee  implements  the  government  policy  of 
protecting natural environment and water resources by monitoring compliance with standards 
for  urban  and  industrial  effluents.  The  State  Sanitary  and  Epidemiological  Inspectorate,  a 
department of the Ministry of Health, implements sanitary supervision of drinking water for 
compliance  with  national  sanitary  norms.  Through  its  provincial  and  district  sanitary  and 
epidemiological services (SES) divisions, the state inspectorate monitors the quality of drinking 
water in both urban and rural distribution networks, and the environmental health conditions in 
public sanitation facilities. 
 
13.  The  day-to-day  WSS  services  are  operated  by  district  and  city  vodokanals.  The 
provincial administration receives reports from the provincial vodokanal, which coordinates and 
monitors the performance of the district and city vodokanals in the province. In addition, six 
interregional  water  supply  agencies  manage  and  operate  interregional  trunk  mains  in  the 
country.  These  agencies  cover  several  districts  or  even  operate  across  provinces.  They 
abstract, transmit, and distribute water to consumers. Some supply water in bulk to district or 
city vodokanals, while others operate as large vodokanals. 
 
14.  Sector Reforms. The Government of Uzbekistan recognizes the need to reform the 
operation and management of the WSS sector according to market economy principles. It has 
therefore begun a number of key reforms including (i) gaining access to external funding for 
capital works, (ii) metering customer supply, (iii) decentralizing responsibility for the day-to-day 
running of the facilities to the vodokanals, and (iv) allowing tariffs to reflect the full cost recovery 
of investment. The WSS sector was targeted for privatization in 2002. But privatization, which in 
this  case  meant  divestment  of  assets,  failed  to  attract  support  because  of  the  lack  of  a 
well-developed regulatory framework, the poor condition of the systems, and the insufficient 
number of qualified private sector investors.

15.  Sector  Development  Targets.  The  National  Water  Supply  Development  Program 
(NWSDP) developed in 1999 targeted close to 100% coverage in most urban areas and 85% in 
rural areas by 2010. This goal is unattainable. World Bank estimates suggest that infrastructure 
investment in the order of $1.4 billion will just about cover the rehabilitation of the infrastructure. 
Twice as much could be needed to increase population coverage and reach the goals of the 
NWSDP.  A  revised  strategy  is  needed  to  revisit  the  targets  and  the  NWSDP,  taking  into 
consideration integrated water resource management, cost-effective options for developing the 
WSS systems, the needed reforms, and nonphysical interventions. 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
16.  The  WSS  systems  inherited  from  the  Soviet  Union  have  reached  the  end  of  their 
economic life and require extensive rehabilitation. The provision of reliable, safe, and affordable 
WSS services to the population, in the face of deteriorated infrastructure, an outdated sector 
strategy  and  planning,  inappropriate  standards,  limited  financial  resources,  and  weak 
institutional capacity, is a key challenge to the Government. A problem tree analysis of the 
sector is presented in Appendix 1. 
 
17.  Infrastructure  Constraints.  Despite  being  increasingly  difficult  to  maintain,  an 
extensive network still exists, albeit operating at low service levels. Most of the systems were 
built with materials and equipment of poor quality. Water supply pipes are made of untreated 
steel,  so  corrosion  presents  a  problem  for  both  short-term  maintenance  and  long-term 
depreciation.  Submersible  pumps  function  for  less  than  a  year  before  requiring  a  major 
overhaul.8 With limited funds, vodokanals routinely rewind burned-out electrical motors and 
carry out “Band-Aid” operations on leaking pipes just to keep the systems operating at a low 
level of service. High-density polyethylene pipes and high-grade equipment are now available in 
the country and, where funds permit, are being used in systems rehabilitation. The assessment 
by the World Bank suggests that 60% of the infrastructure needs to be replaced.  
 
18.  Outdated  Sector  Strategy  and  Planning.  Planning  in  the  sector  remains  highly 
centralized and focused on the simple replacement of pipes, pumps, and wells as the basis for 
determining investment needs. This implies that centralized pipe networks or sewerage systems 
will  be  rehabilitated  or  new  ones  built  exactly  as  they  were  20–50  years  ago.  Alternative 
least-cost solutions are not sought. For the sector to function efficiently, planning must be 
decentralized to allow local planners to develop their own options. Planning data are unreliable, 
and often consist of a collection of physical information (such as kilometers of pipe laid) rather 
than information about key outcomes, such as actual service coverage and quality of service 
provided. The investment plan prepared under the NWSDP covers only investment needs until 
2010 and is outdated and inaccurate. For a more accurate assessment of long-term investment 
needs, a sector road map and a comprehensive sector development program must be prepared 
to reflect actual service coverage and conditions, and identify the measures and investments 
needed to achieve the sector’s goals up to 2020. Although the Government is interested in 
promoting private sector involvement in WSS service provision, policy and regulatory support is 
inadequate and the sector needs to be restructured to attract more private interest. To promote 
public-private partnership (PPP) in the sector more efficiently, a comprehensive study is needed 
to understand the PPP potentials, major constraints, and opportunities. 
 
19.  Inappropriate Standards and Designs. Standards used in Uzbekistan are derived from 
those that were used in the Soviet Union. Consumption levels for consumers have been set at 
100–350 liters per capita per day (lpcd), leading to the design of high-capacity systems and

large pipes and pumps. Systems are thus highly capitalized, and the combination of long 
pipelines and high flow rates have resulted in high energy consumption and high operating 
costs. Rigid design standards make it difficult to apply alternative service options, such as 
tanker delivery to remote rural communities. In the sanitation sector, all wastewater treatment 
plants  follow  a  similar  design.  Alternatives  such  as  stabilization  ponds  (with  anaerobic,

areas with access to agricultural land. Methane gas can be extracted from the anaerobic ponds 
for energy and the treated water used for irrigation. But these options have not yet been 
considered.  
 
20.  Limited  Financial  Resources.  WSS services under the Soviet Union were heavily 
subsidized by the central government. System planning did not focus on cost recovery or 
least-cost design options. Consumption was based on normative design values and tariffs were 
set at a nominal rate and de-linked from required capital and operation and maintenance (O&M) 
costs for sustainable service provision. A disconnection policy was in place but rarely enforced; 
quite often consumers were able to negotiate a partial payment. The cash flow problem this 
created rendered the vodokanals unable to meet O&M costs, let alone depreciation allowance 
and capital requirements for system expansion. As a result, they cut routine maintenance and 
reduced service duration to control operating costs. With no capital reserves, the vodokanals 
often had to resort to emergency funds from the provincial government or even on occasion 
from  the  makhalla 9  committees  to  replace  worn-out  equipment,  often  with  poor-quality 
replacements. The consumers, poorly served, understandably resisted paying for the services. 
The average collection rate is still only about 50%. 
 
21.  Weak Institutional Capacity. Institutional capacity at all levels is weak. UCSA, which is 
responsible  for  the  overall  management  and  development  of  the  sector,  mostly  identifies 
projects for external funding, implements investment projects, and manages interregional trunk 
mains. It has limited capability to address long-term sector needs such as sector strategies and 
plans, as well as guidelines for assessing projects and preparing project proposals, and for 
transmitting  this  information  to  the  provinces.  The  vodokanals,  which  are  responsible  for 
operating the water supply systems, need to manage better and improve their technical capacity. 
Vodokanal staff have little opportunity for internal training. Positions do not come with duty 
statements, and there are no operations manuals or maintenance logs. Functioning offices with 
filing systems are rare. The consumer database does not reflect all consumers and there is little 
customer  orientation.  UFW  is  impossible  to  determine,  and  performance  monitoring  and 
benchmarking systems are rarely adopted. 
 
22.  Need for Integrated Water Resources Management. Water resources management 
for surface waters is the responsibility of the Ministry of Agriculture and Water Resources and 
groundwater that of the State Committee on Geology and Mineral Resources, and the WSS 
sector is under UCSA. While the WSS sector uses only about 3.8% of water resources, high 
standards are required to maintain potable quality. National and provincial planning should 
ensure that estimates of known groundwater reserves are updated regularly, and that resources 
are protected for future use. Leakage of drainage water from irrigation has salinized some 
shallow aquifers, which could have been used as local water sources for rural communities.  
 
23.  The Project will deal with these challenges and support sector development by tackling

management, and (iv) operational and institutional gaps. The Project will work with both national 
and provincial governments. At the national level, the Project will help the Government to build a 
vision and a big picture for the sector as a whole by strengthening the essential policies and

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
27.  When completed in 2014, the Project will improve living standards, the environment, and 
public health for about 340,000 people living in Surkhandarya Province. Its outcome will be safe, 
reliable,  inclusive,  and  sustainable  water  supply  and  sanitation  services  and  improved 
community hygiene. 
B.  Outputs 
28.  The Project has five components: 
1.  Strengthening of Sector Strategy and Management 
29.  This component will promote the economic use of water resources and improve water 
supply and wastewater sector planning and management. It comprises the development of 
(i)   an  integrated  water  sector  profile;  (ii)  a  water  supply  and  wastewater  sector  strategy, 
including a PPP framework; and (iii) a water supply and wastewater sector development road 
map  and  comprehensive  investment  plan.  Sector  issues  and  constraints—restructuring  for 
economic  scale,  least-cost  technical  options  and  models,  corporate  governance  and 
management,  regulatory  framework  and  proper  PPP  models,  tariff  and  cost  recovery,  and 
capacity development—will be analyzed in detail. Reforms recommended for dealing with these 
constraints will be incorporated into an action-oriented road map and reflected in the sector 
investment program. The analytical work will lay a solid foundation for progressively addressing 
the sector development issues. Details of this component are in Supplementary Appendix A. 
2.  Water Supply Development 
30.  This component will develop safe, affordable, and reliable piped water supply systems. It 
involves  the  development  of  (i)  boreholes  at  identified  groundwater  sources,  (ii) water 
transmission facilities, (iii) service reservoirs, (iv) chlorination facilities, (v) distribution networks, 
(vi) individual metered service connections, and (vii) structural improvements in office buildings 
for each subproject. Equipment for O&M of the water supply systems will also be procured 
under this component. Appropriate PPP models for water supply service delivery will also be 
explored and possibly pilot tested, if such potential exists. 
 
31.  The  subprojects  selected 10  all  share  the  following  characteristics:  (i) a  partially 
functioning  water  supply  system,  (ii)  closeness  to  a  surface  or  groundwater  source, 
(iii) closeness to water trunk mains, and (iv) good economic growth prospects. The focus on city 
and district centers and surrounding settlements has three significant advantages. It (i) provides 
a critical mass of domestic consumers and commercial businesses, (ii) allows the vodokanals to 
operate as financially viable enterprises, and (iii) establishes a strong core operational group, 
which will allow phased expansion to other settlements in future years.

C.  Special Features 
35.  Long–Term Partnership and Public-Private Partnerships. The Project will pave the 
way for a long-term partnership with the Government in the WSS sector. It will work with both 
national and provincial governments. At the national level, the Project will help the Government 
build a vision for the sector by strengthening the essential policies and strategies, developing a 
sector road map, and preparing a comprehensive sector development program and a PPP 
framework. At the provincial level, the Project will set up an urban WSS services model in 
Surkhandarya Province, which can be replicated and expanded in other provinces. Besides 
investments in physical infrastructure for system rehabilitation and necessary upgrading, the 
Project will address the critical planning, management, financial, operational, and customer 
relations needs of the provincial and district vodokanals. Private operators will be involved in the 
formulation of sector strategy and the design of the PPP framework. PPP pilot projects11 will be

implementation will ensure that the sector strategy and PPP framework are responsive to

36.  Change  in  Business  Culture  and  Management. Because of the heavy subsidies 
traditionally provided to the sector, as well as the deteriorated systems, inadequate resources, 
low tariffs, and poor payment discipline in the sector, water supply in Uzbekistan is widely 
perceived  to  be  a  loss-suffering  business.  The  vodokanals  have  become  reactive  service 
providers  without  adequate  incentives  to  expand  their  customer  base.  As  a  result,  their 
management  is  not  forward-looking,  their  staff  members  are  inadequately  motivated,  daily 
operating procedures are abandoned, and consumer complaints are not properly recorded and 
responded to. The Project will demonstrate the financial viability of water supply services and 
make  the  vodokanals  more  autonomous  and  accountable,  by  investing  in  infrastructure 
improvements, introducing needed institutional and financial reforms, and enhancing the skills 
and capability of vodokanal staff. Vodokanals will be given more incentives to improve their 
performance and expand their business, procedures will be prepared and implemented in daily 
operations, performance will be benchmarked, and a consumer complaint mechanism will be 
developed and adopted. The vodokanals should thus be transformed gradually from reactive to 
business-oriented service providers, with a forward-looking strategy and internal incentives to 
upgrade knowledge and skills, control costs, improve performance, and expand their customer 
base. Consumers’ rights and customer contracts between the vodokanals and their customers 
will become a core part of the vodokanals’ business culture. 
 
37.  Metering. The water meter is the cash register and a critical management tool in water 
supply  systems.  Together  with  volumetric  pricing,  it  provides  an  incentive  for  water 
conservation, thereby  protecting water resources and enabling the postponement of costly 
system expansion. It also allows vodokanals to better locate distribution losses and charge for 
water consumption on the basis of use—generally perceived to be the fairest way of allocating 
the costs of water supply to users. However, most water consumers and water production and 
pumping facilities in Uzbekistan are not metered, preventing vodokanals from properly planning, 
charging  for,  and  measuring  their  operation.  The  Project  will  provide  water  meters  for  all 
production, distribution, and consumption, and thereby create an essential foundation for many 
aspects of vodokanal operations, including business planning and management, water loss 
reduction, efficient O&M, revenue collection, and performance measurement and targeting. 
 
38.  Performance  Benchmarking.  Performance  benchmarking  is  another  important 
management  and  planning  tool  for  utility  management.  The  results  of  the  benchmarking 
program will help sector decision makers and vodokanal managers understand more precisely 
water supply service performance, difficulties, and challenges, and compare performance with 
other water utilities in the region, the country, and even worldwide. The decision makers and 
managers  can  thus  come  up  with  more  relevant  decisions  and  actions  to  improve  sector 
management and development, set realistic service targets, and strengthen the performance of 
vodokanals. Performance benchmarking is also essential in sector regulation and provides 
important reference information for setting service standards and reviewing tariffs. Performance 
benchmarking is not practiced in Uzbekistan, however, mainly because there are not enough 
meters installed. Once meters are installed, the Project will help each subproject vodokanal 
develop and implement a simple benchmarking system with one or two indicators for each key 
performance area (technical, financial, institutional, and customer services). Training will be 
provided to build the capacity to collect, analyze, and compare the data as part of ongoing 
performance monitoring. This process of performance monitoring will help set the basis for 
further reforms in the sector, including PPPs.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACT, AND RISKS 
60.  General Gains. The Project will benefit approximately 340,000 residents by 2014 and 
367,000 residents by 2020 in the project areas by providing safe, reliable and inclusive piped 
water supplies, improving sanitation, and promoting good hygiene behaviors. About 20% of the 
population of the province, and nearly 90% of the urban residents and over 30% of the rural 
residents in the project areas, will benefit. The health benefits from the physical investments in 
safe water supply will be maximized as people become more knowledgeable and better aware 
of health and hygiene issues and are able to avoid the drudgery associated with collecting 
water, particularly for women. The economy of the region will benefit from increased productivity 
as health improves, less time is needed to collect water, and water supply services become 
more reliable. Town residents will also benefit from lower water costs and from savings in 
health-care costs. 
 
61.  Poverty Reduction. All the project interventions will have a positive impact on the poor 
directly or indirectly. They will compose about 32% of the 340,000 project beneficiaries. Socially 
inclusive processes built into the Project will ensure that the poor benefit proportionately. They 
will benefit through reduced drudgery, improved health, and reduced expenditure on health 
care. Households will not be required to pay a connection charge and the costs of the meters 
will be payable in installments over 3 years. Both policies will help make safe water supply more 
accessible to the poor. The tariffs recommended will be affordable to the poor. Systems will be 
developed for monitoring equity of access to safe and reliable water supply in poor communities 
and at the project administration level, and a national social, poverty, and gender expert will be 
recruited to oversee this monitoring throughout the Project. Together with the UCSA, the expert 
will monitor the socioeconomic implications of the Project through all its phases as part of the 
PPMS. A summary poverty reduction and social development strategy is in Appendix 10. 
 
62.  Gender Impact. While both men and women will benefit from project investments and 
activities, women will benefit more from time savings, reduced drudgery, and improved family 
health. Women perform the bulk of household work with the help of children, particularly girls. 
They are generally responsible for water collection, family hygiene and sanitation, and care for

16 
sick family members. The socioeconomic analysis revealed that women and children spend an 
average of 2 hours each day collecting water. Particular attention will be given to involving 
women  in  employment,  management,  decision  making,  and  learning  and  training  activities 
under the Project. A national social, poverty, and gender expert will be hired to ensure the 
mainstreaming of gender in all Project components, especially the activities related to capacity 
building, training, hygiene, sanitation, and monitoring and evaluation. A gender action plan 
based on the gender analysis in Supplementary Appendix E can be found in Appendix 11. 
 
63.  Ethnic Minority Groups. The Project will not affect any indigenous peoples defined as 
such in ADB’s Policy on Indigenous Peoples (1998). The project areas are fairly homogeneous 
in ethnic composition. Eighty percent of the residents are Uzbek. The most numerous among 
the other ethnic groups are the Tajik, who can be found in all the project districts and are a 
majority population (55%) in Sariasiya district. About 100 Multan18 families live in Kizirik and 
Sariasiya districts. People of other ethnicities are not many. The various ethnic groups do not 
differ in their water supply and sanitation needs. All will benefit directly from piped water supply, 
sanitation improvements, and better hygiene. A report on ethnic minorities (Supplementary 
Appendix F) prepared for the Project assesses the impact of the Project on ethnic groups, 
according to government regulations and ADB’s Policy on Indigenous Peoples. 
 
64.  Land Acquisition and Resettlement. The Project will not require any land acquisition 
and resettlement (LAR), and there will be no impact on structures since the pipelines will be laid 
along existing roads and pathways. Only one subproject (Djarkurgan) will have some impact in 
the form of crop losses and temporary land occupation, and will require a short resettlement 
plan that conforms to ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995). This subproject will affect 
21 households (156 persons). For each of the seven other subprojects, the absence of impact is 
documented in the due-diligence reports prepared by the EA. The short resettlement plan and 
the due-diligence reports will be reviewed after detailed design, and updated plans and reports 
will be submitted to ADB for approval before construction. The resettlement will be monitored by 
UCSA, with the help of international and national resettlement experts. The social safeguards 
are  summarized  in  Appendix  12,  the  short  resettlement  plan  for  Djarkurgan  is  in 
Supplementary Appendix G, and the due-diligence reports assessing the need for LAR for the 
remaining subprojects are in Supplementary Appendix H.  
 
65.  Environmental Impact. The Project is classified as category B according to ADB’s 
Environmental Policy (2002) and Environmental Assessment Guidelines (2003). The provision 
of safe drinking water and proper sanitation facilities is expected to have a significant positive 
impact on the environment. Simple, appropriate, low-cost technology with no significant adverse 
environmental consequences will be used. The quality of the water resources selected for 
development has been reviewed and fit ADB norms. Any negative environmental impact will 
mainly be short term, possibly occurring during construction, and can easily be minimized by the 
proposed  mitigation  measures  and  environmentally  sound  engineering  and  construction 
practices. Initial environmental examination (IEE), including separate assessments for each of 
the eight subprojects (Supplementary Appendix I), has been carried out for the Project. The IEE 
showed  no  significant  adverse  environmental  impact.  The  environmental  mitigation  and 
monitoring procedures in the environmental management and monitoring plan (EMMP) will be 
followed to avoid the standard construction impact. A budget of $385,000 has been allocated for 
EMMP  implementation.  The  activities  include the  cleanup  of construction sites, the  proper 
disposal of spoils, the grading and revegetation of damaged land, and protection of the public 
from  excessive  noise  and  dust  during  construction,  among  other  standard  environmental 
procedures. A report on the implementation of the EMMP during construction will be submitted 
to ADB every 6 months. The summary IEE is in Appendix 13.

66.  Institutional Impact. The Project will help the Government define a coherent vision and 
strategy  for  WSS  sector  development,  with  which  the  Government  can  coordinate  more 
effectively the development activities in the sector, including those of its development partners. 
The recommendations in the PPP framework for tapping PPP potential and addressing the 
constraints will enable the Government to promote greater private sector involvement in WSS. 
The  institutional  reforms  intended  to  transform  vodokanals  into  business-oriented  service 
providers—financial and tariff reforms, customer registration, complaint redress mechanisms, 
and  performance  benchmarking—together  with  the  management  tools  and  capacity 
development programs, will provide vodokanals with more internal incentives and capability to 
deliver better WSS services.  
 
67.  Economic Analysis. Economic benefits will be gained from improved access to safer, 
more reliable, and affordable water supply and a cleaner environment in the project areas. 
Economic analysis for the water supply component in each subproject area, according to ADB’s 
guidelines and handbook,19 identified the following quantifiable economic benefits of improved 
water supply services: non-incremental water consumption, valued at the average price20 of 
water supplied from non-piped sources; and incremental water consumption, valued at the price 
consumers are willing to pay. The eight subprojects have an economic internal rate of return 
(EIRR) ranging from 24.4% to 39.7%, for an average EIRR of about 32.1%. The economic 
analysis is in Appendix 14, and detailed calculations are in Supplementary Appendix J. 
 
68.  Financial Evaluation. At present, costs related to the development and reconstruction 
of water supply systems are not considered in tariff determination. Water loss, electricity, and 
other material consumption norms are. However, with the networks and equipment in their 
current state of deterioration, actual consumption exceeds the norms; hence, tariffs do not cover 
actual O&M expenses. Under the Project, tariffs will be increased to levels that will allow the full 
recovery of O&M expenses, taxes, and depreciation by the vodokanals. The financial and 
affordability analyses show that the tariffs proposed under the Project, on the basis of the above 
principles, are affordable to all, including the poor households. If these tariffs are implemented, 
the financial internal rate of return (FIRR) for each subproject will be 5.1%–5.8%, higher than 
the weighted average cost of capital (WACC) of 4.2%. All vodokanals are expected to have 
positive net cash flows after the project facilities start operating in 2014; no additional subsidy 
will  be  needed.  The  financial  analysis  is  presented  in  Appendix  15,  and  details  are  in 
Supplementary Appendix K. 
 
69.  Risks. Five possible risks have been identified and addressed in the project design. 
First,  the  risk  of lack  of  commitment  to  a  comprehensive  sector  strategy  and  investment 
program is addressed by the broadly consultative and participatory approach to the strategy 
study, to ensure government ownership of the strategy, road map, and investment program. 
Second, to avert delays in project start-up caused by the delayed preparation and approval of 
nationwide feasibility study, feasibility studies for all the subprojects have been conducted and 
completed in parallel with the project preparation and the Government has endorsed these 
studies before loan negotiations. Third, to forestall delays in the provision of local counterpart 
funds, assurances have been obtained from the Government that it will allocate and provide the 
funds on time. Fourth, given the limited capability of vodokanals to meet the incremental O&M of 
the  expanded  water  supply  systems,  the  capacity  development  component  of  the  Project 
includes management improvement activities, tariff and financial reforms, and targeted training. 
Lastly, to guard against the adverse effects of resettlement on poor and vulnerable households,

I.  POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A. Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
  
The Government of Uzbekistan, in coordination with international organizations, supported an in-depth poverty analysis in late 
July 2007. The Welfare Improvement Strategy and Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper (WIS/PRSP 2008–2010)a sets out a 
strategy for improving living standards, especially for low-income and socially isolated groups. The strategy emphasizes the 
need to improve access to municipal services that ensure decent living conditions (potable water supply has first priority) to 
improve living standards. In this regard, the large gap between large urban centers and rural areas in access to infrastructure 
widens the gap in living standards. Since 1990 the Government has implemented a targeted program for providing the 
population with clean potable water, which has increase the proportion of households with access to potable water supply, 
from 50% in 1990 to 82.6% by the start of 2007. According to the WIS, 1,312 more populated localities should be provided 
with centralized water supply by 2008. 
ADB’s country strategy and program (2006–2010)b is well aligned with the Government’s WIS/PRSP and is aimed at 
promoting pro-poor growth through four key strategic priorities. Of these four, the Project will directly contribute to the 
attainment of these two priorities: 
(i)  Accelerating environmentally sustainable rural development. Through the delivery of improved and more 
accessible water supply to more households in the urban as well as rural areas of Surkhandarya Province, the 
Project will enable families to participate more fully in economic activities, and reduce the costs of health care 
due to water-related illnesses. Improvements in sanitation and hygiene promotion in schools will help maximize 
the health benefits from safe water supply.  
(ii)  Building the human capital of the poor. The Project will contribute to poverty reduction efforts by improving 
water supply to the poor and female-headed households, and by delivering school sanitation and hygiene 
programs. 
Assistance from international donors to the municipal services sector is critical. A number of projects that will supply safe 
drinking water and wastewater treatment facilities are being prepared or implemented. Technical assistance is also required 
for municipal services reform. The Government is planning reforms in municipal services, and the Project will contribute to 
(i) a gradual transition of municipal services enterprises from dependency on the government to financial independence; 
(ii) improved rate-setting policies and transparency; (iii) targeted support for low-income population groups; (iv) improved 
maintenance,  repairs,  and  funding  for  the  municipal  services  system;  (v)  sustainable  funding  for  the  construction  of 
interregional piped water supply systems; (vi) regional programs that will promote economic reforms; and (vii) a greater role 
for local self-governing bodies (makhallas) in regulating municipal services and housing relationships.

1. Key Issues  
 According to a World Bank study (2003) based on a household budget survey in the southern economic region, which 
includes Surkhandarya Province, 27.6% of the population is living below the poverty line.c The PPTA socioeconomic survey 
conducted in 2007–2008 showed a household poverty rate of 33% in the seven subproject areas of Surkhandarya and 31% in

month in Termez and $19.4 per month in the seven other subproject areas. The average monthly income of families is $207 in 
Termez and $173 in the other seven areas. The average per capita income of the poor is one–third the income of the 
nonpoor. Only 46.4% of the families surveyed were urban residents. 
Numerous studies, including the WIS, indicate that poverty in small towns in Uzbekistan is even higher than the poverty in 
rural areas, as access to land is limited for families in small towns, and there are much fewer employment opportunities in the 
state-funded  sector  and  in  private  business  and  industry  than  in  big  cities.  Income  from  hired  employment  in  the 
nonagricultural sector is most significant for poor families, even in the small semi-urban settlements (27% of total income in 
Surkhandarya Province). The second-most-important income sources are social transfers and the marketing of agricultural 
products grown by the families themselves. Pensions and social transfers (including the social benefits of low-income 
households) contribute 23.9% of the income of poor families in Surkhandarya. Poor families have a higher share of 
unemployment (62%). More than 70% of the unemployed are women. Most of the poor are hired workers, employed in the 
agricultural or state-funded sectors, or self-employed people who cultivate their own small household plots (up to 0.1 hectare). 
Poor families spend about 48%–53% of total family income for foodstuffs. The level of meat product consumption is up to 
required standards only in 12% of families, while most of the diet is mostly carbohydrates (flour, potato) and fats (vegetable 
oil). The education level of poor families is close to the national average of 91% having gone through primary school.

II.  SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.        Findings of Social Analysis 
The population of the settlements in the subproject areas, which comprise eight administrative districts, is more than 340,000 
(127,000 in Termez and 213,000 in the other seven area), or about 69,700 families. The average family size is 5 persons in 
Termez and 5.9 persons in the other areas. Family size is bigger for poor households (6 persons in Termez and 6.6 in the 
seven other areas) compared with nonpoor households (4.6 in Termez and 5.6 in the other areas). Ninety-eight percent of 
families live in their own houses, with land for a family house guaranteed by the state.  
Potable water supply in the project areas is worsening. There are no metering devices, water supply is unreliable, and the 
population is unwilling to pay the current rates. According to the PPTA socioeconomic survey data, most of the households 
surveyed, irrespective of their living standards, are face with a shortage of potable water. The average consumption of water 
for drinking and household needs per day is less than 13 liters per capita (about 80 liters per family per day, versus the official 
standard of 110 liters per capita per day). Ninety percent of Termez households and only 42% of the households in the seven 
other districts have piped water in their houses. However, over 13% of connections have never worked, and the rest are 
inoperable more than half of the time. No less than 35% of families in the project areas take water from several sources at a 
time and use it for drinking and household needs. As a rule, even families that have piped water in their houses often use 
water from a water post in the street for drinking and household needs (some 55% of families) or water brought by water 
vendors, or even water from canals.  
Diarrhea incidence is five to seven times higher among families that take water from open water reservoirs than among 
families with piped water. On average, the annual expenses for diarrhea treatment amount to about 8.7% of monthly family 
income in the seven project districts and 6.9% in Termez. An average of 30% of children under 14 (male and female, urban 
and rural) bathe less than once a week. About 46% of the household time of Termez residents is spent collecting water, 
compared with 75.3% for households in the seven other districts. Average distance to the main source of water is less than 
100 meters in Termez and more than 600 meters in the remaining subproject areas. An average family spends about 3.75 
person-days per month collecting water, versus 6.1 person-days per month in the other subproject districts. About 90%–95% 
of families store water for their drinking and household needs. Expenses on the construction of water storage reservoirs 
(khauzes) are especially high, amounting to $150 each. 
Because of the lack of water, about half of households do not have special rooms for bathing. Although 43% of families 
surveyed said that their houses have bathrooms, almost all have to bring water in buckets to those rooms. Only 24% of

C.  Gender and Development 
1.  Key Issues.  
The role of women in economy is extremely important, as women make up 47% of the labor resources of Uzbekistan. In the 
project areas 47.5% of Surkhandarya women are at least temporarily employed. Despite the fact that women make a 
significant contribution to household budgets (35% of household income), they are employed mostly in the state-funded sector 
or do low-skilled manual labor, receiving lower wages than men. In the agricultural sector women can obtain only seasonal, 
low-skilled manual jobs. Women’s wages are about 80% of men’s wages. 
Moreover, women take on the additional burden of housework, which is quite heavy. Women collect water, cultivate garden 
plots, tend the livestock and poultry, do the laundry, clean the house, cook, and take care of the children and older family 
members. Nine percent of those surveyed in Termez and 58% in the remaining districts do not have a source of water in their 
house yards and have to collect water elsewhere every day. Water delivery is largely (in 80% of cases) a responsibility of 
women and children, who have to bring home water twice or thrice a day, carrying 20–25 liters at a time. As potable water is 
generally of low quality, there is high incidence of water-related diseases among children (diarrhea was reported among 8% of 
all families in Termez and 11% in the seven other districts in the last 12 months). 
Providing households with adequate and good-quality potable water will have a positive impact on women. It will lighten their 
work and allow them to spend more time in gainful employment. It also will have a positive impact on the health of all family 
members, especially children, further lessening the time pressures on women, who must also care for the old and the infirm 
among their household members.

A.  Physical Components 
1.  The main physical components of the Project will involve the following interventions: (i) the 
rehabilitation of 53.3 kilometers (km) of existing trunk mains and the construction of 24.4 km of new 
trunk  mains,  (ii)  the  rehabilitation  of  147.95  km  of  existing  distribution  networks  and  the 
construction of 107.9 km of new distribution networks at existing water distribution centers (WDCs), 
(iii) the  rehabilitation  of  19  existing  water  reservoirs  and  the  construction  of  eight  new  water 
reservoirs, (iv) the rehabilitation of 47 existing boreholes and the construction of 11 new boreholes, 
(v) the rehabilitation of 44 existing pumping stations and the construction of four new pumping 
stations, (vi) the development of existing sanitation zones around water distribution centers, and 
(vii) the rehabilitation and construction of water treatment facilities (chlorination rooms at WDCs). In 
addition, the Project will rehabilitate toilet facilities in schools. The Project targets a population of 
340,000 in 2014 and 367,000 in 2020. 
B.  Existing Environment  
1.  Physical Environment 
 
2.  Surkhandarya  River,  the  main  natural  drainage  system  in  Surkhandarya  Province, 
originates in western Tajikistan, enters the Surkhandarya Province at the northeastern boundary of 
the province, and discharges into the Amu Darya River. The province has extensive artificial 
irrigation and drainage systems and some associated reservoirs. Part of the groundwater in the 
province  is  salinized,  with  total  dissolved  solids  content  often  exceeding  5  grams  per  liter. 
However, there are aquifers with variable amounts of freshwater reserves in some of the project 
districts in Surkhandarya Province. The quality of the groundwater is generally good. 
2.  Socioeconomic Environment 
3.  The  average  household  size  in  the  project  districts  is  5.9  persons,  and  5  persons  in 
Termez.  A  typical  poor  household  consists  of  6.6  persons.  The  project  preparatory  technical 
assistance socioeconomic survey in 2007–2008 showed a household poverty rate of 33% in the 
seven subproject districts and 31% in Termez City. The poverty line in monetary terms is $37 per 
month  in  Termez  City  and  $19.4  in  the  subproject  districts.  Only  42%  of  households  in  the 
subproject districts have access to piped water in their homes, while in Termez City access is 
about 90%. However, 13% of these connections have never worked, and the rest operate for an 
average of 8.4 hours per day in the subproject districts and 11.2 hours per day in Termez City. In 
the summer water supply interruptions are more frequent. Further, 45% of households in the 
subproject districts use water from open water reservoirs (river, canal) at least sometimes for 
household  needs,  including  more  than  20%  of  households  that  use  river  water  for  drinking. 
Consequently,  there  is  a  high  incidence  of  water-related  diseases.  On  average  the,  annual 
expenses for diarrhea treatment amount to about 10% of monthly family income per sick child. 
About half of households surveyed in the seven subproject districts and nearly 30% of households 
in Termez City do not have a special room designated for bathing, and only 5% of households in 
the seven project districts have bathrooms connected to water pipelines. About 50% of the adults 
and 30% of the children bathe only once a week. In the rural settlements of the seven subproject 
areas, no households have access to a central sewerage system. Human waste is dumped into 
non-ventilated pit latrines in domestic gardens. Most of the toilets in the surveyed households are 
not  equipped  with  leakproof  concrete  lining.  In  general,  only  45%  of  the  130  schools  in  the 
subproject areas are connected to piped water supply, and only two schools have a centralized

sewerage  system.  Other  social  infrastructure  in  the  project  areas  (kindergartens,  colleges,

3.  Biological Environment 
4.  Protected nature areas currently cover 4.6% of the country’s territory. However, these areas 
are found in remote areas, far from the project areas. There are two state reserves (protected 
nature areas or wildlife habitats) of national or local importance near or within the perimeter of 
Surkhandarya Province, but only one 20 km from Termez City is near a subproject area. In all 
subproject areas, irrigated agriculture is intensely developed and does not offer ideal refuge to wild

nonirrigated lands differs with the relief. In lowlands grow couch grass, motley grass, and pistachio

common species, including rodents, reptiles, insects, and arachnoids. Typically farm livestock is 
found  in  pasture  land  (Gissar  sheep,  goats).  The  proposed  rehabilitation  and  construction 
subproject interventions are not expected to have a significant long-term impact on the present 
vegetation and animal world.

5.  The eight subproject areas are located between Dushanbe and Termez. Cultural heritage

C.  Potential Environmental Impact and Mitigation Measures 
1.  Environmental Impact Caused by the Project Location 
6.  The land in the project areas is generally agricultural or non-valuable. The subproject 
interventions will nearly all be undertaken in or around existing water supply facilities (water 
distribution  centers,  sanitation  zones)  and  along  existing  water  supply  lines  (main  trunks, 
distribution system); long-term environmental impact caused by the project location is therefore not 
expected. The source of water will frequently be tested before the final decision for development. 
The results of the quality tests must prove that the water is suitable as raw water to be used for 
drinking. The long-term design yield of each production well added to the yield of other wells 
already in use must not exceed the aquifer’s sustainable annual recharge.  
2.  Impact Related to Design 
7.  The  Project  mostly  entails  the  rehabilitation  or  construction  of  groundwater  wells  and 
transmission channels, and facilities in and around the potable water supply systems. The design 
is based on the extraction of potable groundwater through pumps and its transmission through 
distribution networks and treatment to water users. In four of the eight subprojects the feasibility 
team considered alternative designs, and in each case selected the most cost-effective. From an 
environmental  point  of  view,  there  were  no  differences  between  the  options  considered.  No 
environmental implications are expected from the improvements that will be made in the water 
intake structures. Transmission mains will be laid as much as possible along existing roads. 
Transmission mains, distribution networks, and in-yard connections will be of nonmetallic pressure 
pipes, recommended for domestic and drinking water supply, and complying with international 
standards. Typically these will include high-density polyethylene pipes, and polyvinyl chloride and 
carbon fiber or cement (Hobbes) pipes. No asbestos cement pipes will be used. Steel pipes will be

control  will  be  intensified  in  makhallas  during  the  rehabilitation  or  construction  period,  and 
adequate warning will be provided to enhance the safety of schoolchildren.

masks by operators.

includes provision for the training of the project management unit (PMU) and PIU personnel in 
environmental procedures. To facilitate monitoring, an environmental monitoring group (EMG) will 
be set up and will be composed of the following: (i) the senior environment specialist–cum–group 
leader, (ii) the environment expert, and (iii) a representative of the provincial administration. The 
EMG members will be national experts. A report on the environment and the implementation of the 
EMMP will be prepared and sent by the Borrower to the ADB every 6 months during project 
implementation. 
F.  Public Consultations and Information Disclosure 
22.  Consultations have been conducted with the responsible national and provincial institutions, 
district  administrations,  and  other  interested  parties  in  Surkhandarya  Province.  A  stakeholder

Appendix 13  53
   
seminar was organized in Termez on 10 July 2007; there were 61 participants, including provincial 
and district authorities, technical vodokanal staff, representatives of rural assemblies, and women’s 
groups. The main technical project interventions and their main environmental and social impact 
were explained to participants, who were invited to respond, express their opinions, and provide 
input on (i) technical solutions and the scope of work, (ii) the current state of the environment in the 
project  areas,  (iii)  environmentally  related  social  and  resettlement  issues,  and  (iv)  planned 
mitigation  measures  and  monitoring  during  rehabilitation  or  construction  and  operation.  The 
discussions and comments provided essential background, particularly with regard to overcoming 
groundwater contamination and other negative impact. Subsequently, close focus meetings and 
discussions  with  local  stakeholders  particularly  makhalla  associations,  public  and  women’s 
societies and nongovernment organizations, and district administration representatives were held 
in the course of social, resettlement, and environmental studies. The concerns expressed were 
related  mainly  to  land  occupation,  wastewater,  scope  of  work,  and  the  planned  schedule  of 
technical interventions. There was general consensus that continuous availability of drinking water 
would be a substantially positive improvement for health and sanitation. A second stakeholder 
seminar in Termez was conducted in July 2008. The EMMP budget includes an allocation for 
stakeholder meetings during construction. 
G.  Conclusions and Recommendations 
23.  The Project is aimed at improving the health of people—340,000 in all by 2014—who now 
suffer from lack of water supply and adequate sanitation facilities. Negative impact is limited in 
extent, can be prevented by implementing the EMMP, and can eventually be easily mitigated. 
Further study into adequate solutions for the increased wastewater volumes that will result from the 
Project is recommended. The development schemes adopted represent the least-cost solutions as 
well as the most environmentally compatible alternatives. The Project is a necessary step toward 
improving the economic development and poverty alleviation prospects of the province. Failure to 
implement the Project would lead to deterioration of health, increase in poverty, and increase in 
emigration—particularly among young people in search of better living opportunities in cities or 
abroad.  There  is  a  well-structured  environmental  institutional  framework  at  the  central  and 
provincial levels. Procedures for the examination of environmental compliance are well in place 
and tested. The legal basis is exhaustive and substantially covers the various environmental 
sectors. Threats to human health will be practically negligible during construction and in the long 
term. The proposed EMMP should be implemented and revised promptly when needed.

54  Appendix 14 
ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
A.  Introduction and Methodology 
1.  The  economic  analysis  covers  the  Project  as  a  whole,  as  well  as  each  individual 
subproject, and will be undertaken according to Asian Development Bank (ADB) guidelines, 
including the guidelines and handbook for the economic analysis of projects, particularly those 
in  the  water  supply  sector.1 For  the  overall  project,  the  analysis  describes  the  economic 
rationale, the rationale for public intervention, and the setting of the without-project situation. 
The analysis assumes that without the Project, the existing systems’ supply capacity will remain 
the same as in 2008. The economic analysis also evaluates the cost-effectiveness of individual 
subprojects,  focusing  on  the  least-cost  analysis.  The  subproject  analysis  compares  the 
economic internal rate of return (EIRR) with the economic opportunity cost of capital (EOCC), 
assumed  at  12%  as  applied  in  infrastructure  project  studies  undertaken  in  Uzbekistan. 
Sensitivity and risk analyses are undertaken to assess the robustness of the subproject under 
adverse  economic  conditions.  The  analysis  uses  shadow  pricing  and  standard  conversion 
factors  to  convert  the  financial  cost  and  benefits  into  economic  terms.  The  analysis  is 
undertaken in constant May 2008 prices. Details of the economic analysis are presented in 
Supplementary Appendix J. 
B.  Economic Rationale 
2.  The collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991 brought about the sudden stoppage of funding 
and  subsidies  to  the water  supply  and  sanitation  (WSS)  sector  in Uzbekistan.  Uzbekistan 
inherited an enormous number of WSS systems (mostly overdesigned) that are reaching the 
end of their useful life. The amount of the capital investment required to rehabilitate or upgrade 
the systems cannot be met solely by the national and local budgets;2 as a result, the water 
supply system in the country is faced with further deterioration. To arrest the continued decline 
of  water  supply  services,  the  Government  has  begun  a  number  of  key  reforms  including 
(i) improvements in water sector services through a national water supply development plan; 
(ii) financial sustainability goals through cost recovery; (iii) adequate investment planning with 
domestic and external funding; (iv) further decentralization of WSS services; (v) private sector 
participation  and  public-private  partnerships  in  the  sector;  (vi) the  conservation  of  water 
resources, the economic use of water, consistent water quality control, and sound management 
of  wastewater;  and  (vii)  improvements  in  operational  strategies  through  a  stronger  sector 
institutional set-up and interagency collaboration, and adequate capacity building. 
 
3.  Government  intervention  derives  its  rationale  from  the  increasing  concern  over  the 
worsening water supply situation in Surkhandarya Province, where low and declining coverage 
is being made worse by the slow pace of development in the sector. Water supply systems are 
owned and managed by the vodokanals. However, studies show that where such centralized 
systems exist, services only continue to worsen because the vodokanals, lacking funds and 
capacigty, can do very little to improve and rehabilitate the systems. Low tariffs plus significant 
water losses in the systems result in very limited revenue generation, which, in many cases, 
cannot even cover the required operation and maintenance (O&M) costs. The private sector in 
the  water  supply  sector  is  still  not  developed.  Consequently,  large-scale  system  repair  or 
extension works can be financed only with government support. Despite government efforts to

Analysis of Water Supply Projects. Manila. 
2  The World Bank estimates that $1.4 billion is needed to replace or rehabilitate existing infrastructure.

rehabilitate WSS systems in the selected districts, access to water supply is inadequate3 even 
in  district  centers.  The  supply  shortage  has  had  a  negative  impact  on  the  health  of  the 
population, particularly the poor, who are the most affected, as recent studies have confirmed.4 
The water supply systems are in various stages of deterioration and are only partially functional. 
Without urgent major investments in supply and distribution networks, water supply systems will 
continue to deteriorate rapidly, with serious economic and environmental consequences. 
 
4.   Government involvement is justified because of the significant positive externalities 
associated with water supply and sanitation services and their natural monopoly conditions. 
Moreover, there is significant scope for the improvement of water supply and sanitation services 
in  Uzbekistan  through  the  provision  of  financial  and  technical  support  and  institutional 
strengthening, which at present can be provided effectively only by the Government. 
C.  Demand Analysis 
5.  Water demand in the subproject areas has been constrained by the deterioration of the 
piped water systems and their limited capacity to supply consumers. Actual consumption is 
difficult to ascertain from the vodokanals’ records, since only a few consumers are metered. The 
socioeconomic survey5 revealed that water supply from the vodokanals averages 13.3 liters per 
capita per day (lpcd) in Termez City and 12.5 lpcd in the seven other subproject areas. 
 
6.  The low water supply from the vodokanals is augmented by other water supply sources 
that include water vendors, reservoirs, wells, canals, and rivers. Average consumption from 
these additional sources is about 11.3 lpcd. 
 
7.  The population in the service area is projected to grow by 1.11% yearly from 2008 to 
2010, and by 1.23% from 2011 onward. Service coverage is projected to increase gradually 
from the current level to about 95% by 2020. Projected average water demand per capita is 
100 lpcd, with adjustments for institutional, commercial, and industrial use for each subproject. 
This  figure  is  based  on  the  standard  adopted  by  the  Government.  While  metering  the 
consumption and increasing tariffs will result in a lower consumption rate, the increased income 
will  offset  the  reduction  in  consumption  rate.  Given  this  per  capita  demand,  the  designed 
capacity is projected to meet water demand up to 2020. From 2021 and onward, it is assumed 
that water supply will remain at the 2020 level. 
D.  Least-Cost Analysis 
8.  Technical  alternatives  for  four  subprojects6—components  considered  essential  in  a 
sustainable  water  supply  system—were  analyzed.  The  choice  of  options  was  based  on 
(i) technical and physical feasibility; (ii) unit supply costs, given the incremental investment and 
O&M costs; and (iii) sustainability of the available water resource. The least-cost solutions were 
chosen for the project design and the cost-benefit analysis.  
                                                 
3 Service coverage levels remain relatively low even after programmed intervention in the past 10 years via the 
national water supply development plan. Studies show that, as of 2006, network coverage in Surkhandarya was 
about 76%. Where it exists, water service is available 6–16 hours per day in urban areas and 2–10 hours in rural 
areas. The rest of the population obtains water from wells and irrigation canals, which are mostly distant, saline, 
and contaminated. 
4 The social survey revealed that there are 10 times more cases of stomach ailments among users of alternative 
sources, especially irrigation canals. 
5  Undertaken during the project design in May 2007 and May 2008. 
6  For the other subprojects, only one technical option was available.
