E.  Economic Costs 
9.  Economic costs exclude taxes and duties. Financial prices were converted to economic 
prices through the use of conversion factors. The shadow exchange rate factor (SERF) was 
assumed to be 1.0. The conversion factor for skilled and unskilled labor was assumed to be 1.0, 
and the shadow wage rate factor (SWRF), 0.8.  
F.  Economic Benefits 
10.  The major economic benefits of improved water supply services are (i) non-incremental 
water consumption, valued at the average economic supply price7 of water from non-piped 
sources; and (ii) incremental water consumption, valued at the price consumers are willing to 
pay8 for the improved water supply services. Benefits that are been deemed difficult to quantify, 
including health benefits from avoided medical costs and fire protection, are recognized but 
were excluded from the analysis.  
G.  Results of Economic Analysis  
11  The EIRR was used to measure the economic effectiveness of the Project. A project with 
an EIRR greater than its EOCC would be considered economically viable. The Project was 
further tested for economic viability under less favorable or even adverse economic conditions. 
Four hypothetical scenarios were formulated to simulate such conditions in the analysis: (i) a 
20% increase in capital cost, (ii) a 20% increase in operating costs, (iii) a 20% decrease in 
revenue, and (iv) a 1-year delay in subproject implementation. 
 
12.  For the eight subprojects, EIRR was calculated to be between 24.4% and 39.7%, with an 
average of 32.1%. Subjected to the sensitivity tests, the subprojects were also found to be 
robust and economically viable. The calculated EIRR is expected to be lower than the true EIRR 
since the economic, social, and environmental implications of not undertaking the subprojects 
are not desirable and can worsen poverty in the project areas.

household per year, according to the survey.

Assessment Component. July.

Appendix 15  57
   
FINANCIAL ANALYSIS 
A.  Introduction 
1.  The Surkhandarya Water Supply and Sanitation Project will cover seven districts and 
Termez City in Surkhandarya Province. The seven districts are Angor, Djarkurgan, Kizirik, 
Kumkurgan,  Muzrabad,  Sariasiya,  and  Shurchi.  Angor  and  Kizirik  districts  are  under  the 
management  of  the  Khodjaipak  Regional  Trunk  Main  Operation  and  Management 
Administration. In Djarkurgan district, two vodokanals (water supply agencies) will be covered—
Djarkurgan vodokanal, which serves the district center; and Surkhan vodokanal, which serves 
the nearby settlements. Capital investments will focus on the rehabilitation of existing water 
supply systems and expansion to settlements near the district centers. 
 
2.  The financial analysis of the water supply component was undertaken in two parts: 
(i) determination of appropriate water tariffs for each subproject that would ensure financial 
sustainability, and (ii) preparation of financial projections for each subproject. The projections 
consisted of annual financial statements (income statement, cash flow statement, and balance 
sheet), key performance indicators, and operating and financial data for 2009–2020. Details of the 
financial analysis are presented in Supplementary Appendix K. 
B.  Bases for Financial Projections 
3.  Price. The financial projections for each subproject are presented on a current price 
basis. Revenues and costs were converted from constant 2008 prices to current prices through 
the use of projected local annual inflation rates as follows: 10.5% in 2009, 10% in 2010, 9% in 
2011 to 2012, 5% in 2013, and 4% from 2014 onward. 1 
 
4.  Financial Objectives. The proposed tariff rates for each subproject were designed to 
(i) fully recover operation and maintenance (O&M) costs, (ii) recover all subproject debt service, 
(iii) maintain a debt service ratio of at least 1.2, and (iv) generate a financial internal rate of 
return  (FIRR)  greater  than  the  weighted  average  cost  of  capital  (WACC)  of  the  Project, 
wherever  feasible,  after  project  completion.  In  addition,  each  subproject  was  projected  to 
maintain its accounts receivable at less than 60 days’ equivalent of annual sales by 2016. 
 
5.  Operating Revenues. Operating revenues include water sales and repayment of water 
meters. Repayment of water meter was assumed to be made in 36 equal monthly installments 
and billed to consumers accordingly. Future water sales were calculated on the basis of water 
demand (Appendix 12) and projected water tariff levels. Tariffs were set in accordance with the 
government policy, i.e., a maximum of 20% per increase, a maximum of two tariff increases per 
year, and a maximum profit of 10%.2  
 
6.  Operating Expenses. Annual O&M costs were projected separately for each subproject 
over  the  entire  forecast  period  by  major  expense  item  (salary,  electricity,  chemicals, 
maintenance, social charges, selling and administration expenses). Depreciation allowance was 
calculated on an average asset life of 20 years using the straight-line method. Income tax was 
assumed to be 10%.

7.  Subproject Cost and Financing Plan. Subproject capital costs will be funded through 
an ADB loan and from government funds. The ADB loan will have a term of 32 years, including 
a grace period of 8 years, and an interest charge of 1% yearly during the grace period and 1.5% 
yearly thereafter. The Government will relend the proceeds of the loan to UCSA under a 
subsidiary loan agreement. The relending will be done on ADB loan terms with an additional 
charge of not more than 0.2% on the ADB interest rate (1.2% during the grace period and 1.7% 
yearly thereafter). UCSA will onlend the proceeds of the subsidiary loan to the subproject 
vodokanals through the Surkhandarya provincial government on the same terms. The provincial 
government will bear the foreign exchange risks.

9.  Affordability.  An  affordability  analysis  was  undertaken  to  ensure  that  household 
consumers, particularly those in the low-income group, can afford the proposed water tariffs. On 
the  generally  accepted  principle  that  the  expenditure  on  water  should  not  exceed  4%  of 
household income, the projected water tariffs are considered affordable. The table above shows 
the ratio of the monthly bills to the monthly household income for the low-income group and the 
average-income group. The monthly bills include payment for the water meters in 36 equal 
monthly installments. 
 
10.  WACC and FIRR. The opportunity cost of the government funds is assumed at 25%, 
including a risk premium. At a funding ratio of 79:21 between ADB and the Government, WACC 
is about 4.2% in constant May 2008 prices. The FIRRs are estimated to range from 5.1% to 
5.8%, with an average of 5.4% for the Project. All FIRRs are higher than the WACC. Sensitivity 
analysis also showed that under the assumed adverse conditions, all eight subprojects would 
still be financially viable. In addition, the proposed tariff rate increases would generate enough 
revenues to recover full O&M costs from 2013 onward. By 2015, annual revenues for all the 
subproject vodokanals are projected to cover all O&M costs and debt service obligations, and a 
debt service ratio of at least 1.2:1 will be maintained. 
D.  Financial Performance of Vodokanals 
11.  Recent  Financial  Performance.  The  last  3  years  of  operation  of  the  subproject 
vodokanals showed a positive net income except for Khodjaipak vodokanal.4 From 2005 to

2007, Surkhan5 vodokanal registered a net income of 2%–3% of total revenue, while the other 
subproject vodokanals registered a net income of less than 1% of total revenue.  
 
12.  Projected  Financial  Performance.  Net  income  is  projected  to  be  positive  for  all 
subprojects from 2017 onward and net cash flow to be positive for all subprojects by 2015, the 
year after the project facilities are put into operation. The negative net income in the beginning 
years for some subprojects is due mainly to the time needed to expand the connections and 
gradually  increase  tariffs.  The  difference  between  the  net  cash  flow  and  net  income 
performance is mainly due to the of time difference between the collection of depreciation 
allowance and the repayment of the loan: interest payments will start in 2015 and principal 
repayment will start in 2017. 
 
13.  Termez vodokanal is projected to post a positive return on net fixed assets (ROA) of 
2.4%–16.3% from 2016 to 2020. Debt service ratio (DSR) will be greater than 1.2 during the 
projection period. Djarkurgan vodokanal is projected to register a net income by 2018, while 
ROA will range from 2.6% to 11.7% from 2017 to 2020. DSR will be greater than 1.2 during the 
projection period. Khodjaipak is projected to show a positive financial performance after project 
completion. The financial projections assumed that the other districts served by Khodjaipak6 
would implement tariff increases to cover annual increase in total O&M costs. DSR would range 
from 4.1 to 18.3, while ROA would range from 8.2% to 34.7%. 
 
14.  Kumkurgan vodokanal is projected to post a net income by 2017 and ROA of 1.1%–
16.3% from 2016 to 2020. DSR will be greater than 1.2 during the projection period. Muzrabad 
vodokanal will generate net income only from 2017 onward, mainly because of higher per capita 
investment, although net cash flow will be positive from 2015 to 2020. DSR will be greater than 
1.2 during the projection period. Sariasiya vodokanal will have a positive net income by 2018 
and a positive net cash flow by 2015. ROA is projected to range from 1.1% to 12.4% from 2016 
to 2020. DSR will range from 1.7 to 6.6 after project completion.  
 
15.  Shurchi vodokanal is projected to register a net income by 2014 and a positive net cash 
flow by 2015. ROA will range from 6.4% to 29.5% from 2015 to 2020. DSR will be greater than 
1.2 during the projection period. Surkhan vodokanal will generate net income starting in 2016 
and a positive net cash flow from 2015 to 2020. The vodokanal will have DSRs greater than 1.2 
during the projection period.
